subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Utter/Ado

messageBody:
Paige Gabhart wrote:
>
>
> Read got rid of the two forms of "utter" present in Shavian after
> testing the alphabet. I assume he found it an unnecessary complication
> which QS could avoid. The alternative form of "utter" is useful for
> writing. Attempting to elevate it to a separate letter seems to be
> taking a step backward to me.
>
> First, Read already decided against the need for the separate letter.
> Do we have any evidence that was a mistake? Secondly, the alternative
> form serves a very useful purpose for hand written QS, and changing that
> by making it a new letter ruins that use. I don't think the BIC or
> Papermate pen companies are in danger of going out of business anytime
> soon, and for the foreseeable future people will continue to write.
> Therefore, anything which negatively impacts the use of QS for
> handwritten communication would not get my vote. And finally, while the
> use of junior QS for typewritten documents works fine, and Paul's new
> font is excellent, I still feel the unique beauty of QS is best
> expressed in the senior form with full use of the half-letters and
> ligatures. I am still waiting and hoping for a font that will allow us
> to produce on our computers what we can see in our handwritten QS.
>

Paige,

Hope you had a good vacation. I think you have missed a lot of the
discussion about why Ado does not work. Take the word arrest. Read would
have us spell it:

Ado Roar Ed Sis Tut

Now take the word urban, spelled

Ado Roar Bob Ado Nun

Notice that both words start with the same two letters, but both words
are pronounced completely different. That means that as a QS reader, I
have to first try to pronounce it as /ɜr/, then if that doesn't work,
try pronounce it as /əˈr/. With words like "area," it becomes more tricky.

The problem is that QS has no good letter or pair of letters for /ɜr/.
The only solution right now is to use Earth for /ɜr/, and use Ado + Roar
for everything else, but then users of senior QS might want to use Earth
in both cases, and anyway Earth may look too much like Ado + Roar to
really solve the problem. But It's worth testing it, anyway.

Paul
